oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Nashville Cats program - Harold Bradley - 2006-08-19
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Interview program on the life and career to date of musician Harold Bradley from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on August 19, 2006.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Harold Bradley; Bill Lloyd;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Contains audio from video and recorded audio experts. Program begins in progress with audio from video. Includes questions from audience. Opening comments by Bill Lloyd. Subjects include: Early years and interest in music -- Influence of his brother Owen Bradley -- First professional engagement at 15 years old and joining the musicians union at 16 years old -- Playing with Ernest Tubb -- Education and joining the US Navy -- Early dance band work and working with Papa John Gordy -- First session work in Chicago with Pee Wee King -- Getting to know Eddy Arnold -- Working with Ivory Joe Hunter -- Building his first studio with his brother and the beginning of the Quonset Hut studio -- Recording Chattanooga Shoe Shine Boy and working with drummer Farris Coursey -- Recording Ray Anthony's Bunny Hop on the stage of the Ryman Auditorium -- Story of recording of Burl Ives' September Song -- Casual style of recording in Nashville studios --

Nashville musicians and singers going to New York City with Shelby Singleton -- Meeting Quincy Jones -- Story about the Jordanaires being asked by Elvis Presley to appear in Las Vegas with him and their decision not to go after advice from Owen Bradley -- Live performance excerpts include; Crying -- Bunny Hop -- Jingle Bell Rock -- Laura's Theme -- History of the Dan Electro six string bass in Nashville -- Story about recording Crazy with Patsy Cline using the six string bass -- Crazy -- Story about playing with Les Paul -- Hearing Roy Orbison's Dream in a movie -- Comparing today's session players to the A team players -- Hank Garland stories -- Story about Ken Nelson, Gene Vincent and the Blue Caps band and recording Be Bop A Lulu -- Presentation of Lifetime Achievement Award from Tom Lee of the American Federation of Musicians -- Closing comments -- End.
